profileText: A Senator from Pennsylvania; born in Philadelphia, Pa., October 21, 1901; attended Chestnut Hill Academy; graduated from Middlesex School in 1919, Harvard University in 1923, and the University of Pennsylvania Law School in 1926; admitted to the bar in 1926 and commenced the practice of law in Philadelphia, Pa.; during the Second World War served with the United States Army Air Corps 1941-1945, attaining the rank of colonel; city controller of Philadelphia 1950-1952; mayor of Philadelphia 1952-1956; member of board of overseers, Harvard University 1953-1958; elected as a Democrat to the United States Senate in 1956; reelected in 1962 and served from January 3, 1957, to January 3, 1969; unsuccessful candidate for reelection in 1968; professor, Temple University 1969; president, World Federalists, U.S.A., 1969-1971; was a resident of Philadelphia, Pa., until his death, January 12, 1990; remains were cremated.

researchRecord.name: 1978. 29 pages. Association of Former Members of Congress.
In John J. Raskob, Democratic National Committee papers, 1928-1938.

1947-1968 (bulk 1956-1968). 44 linear feet. Chiefly documents Senate career including campaigns. Correspondence and memoranda relate to disarmament, United Nations, Vietnam, and other matters before the Foreign Relations Committee. Includes constituent correspondence, press releases, speeches, clippings, legislative files, voting record, television scripts and tapes (1959-1967), principally of a program done with Senator Hugh Scott. A small amount of material pertains to political activities prior to Senate service.
Correspondence in Emma Guffey Miller papers, 1887-1970 (bulk 1920-1970).

1978. 29 leaves. Reminiscences of election to U.S. Senate; support of international disarmament, world peace through world law; relationship with Presidents Kennedy and Johnson; Adlai Stevenson's role in American politics; impressions of various members of Congress. Acquired from Former Members of Congress, Inc. Permission required to cite, quote, and reproduce.
Correspondence in Frank Church papers, 1941-1984. Finding aid.
4 audiotapes (1966-1968) in Westinghouse Broadcasting Company collection, 1945-1981.
1954-1964. .3 foot. Correspondence, press releases, telegrams, photographs, and TV political scripts contained in various collections. Finding aid.

Correspondence in World Association of World Federalists, United Nations Office records, 1967-1982; Abraham Egnal papers, 1949-1968 (bulk 1960-1968); Consortium on Peace, Research, Education, and Development records, 1970-[ongoing]; and Albert Bigelow papers, 1956-1961.

Ca. 45 letters; correspondence in Walter Massey Phillips papers, 1927-1978; a petition in Citizens Committee to Recall Rizzo records, 1976; in National Association for the Advancement of Colored People records, Philadelphia Branch records, 1943-1963; and Americans for Democratic Action, Southeastern Pennsylvania Chapter records, 1947-1967.

In addition to the institutions listed above, items are also cataloged in collections at: Harvard Law School Library, Cambridge, MA; Syracuse University, Syracuse, NY; University of Michigan, Bentley Historical Library, Ann Arbor, MI; University of Pennsylvania, Philadelphia, PA.; University of Virginia, Charlottesville, VA; and Yale University, New Haven, CT.
